**Key Legal Arguments:**

* The petitioner argues that the impugned Act imposes unreasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right to move throughout India, as conferred by Article 19(1)(d) and (e) of the Constitution.
* The respondent argues that the Act imposes reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right, in the interests of the general public and for the protection of the interests of any Scheduled Tribe.

**Critical Judicial Reasoning:**

* The Court considers the scope and ambit of the word "reasonable" as applied to restrictions on the exercise of the right, and concludes that it does not necessarily exclude from consideration the question of reasonableness of the procedural part of the law.
* The Court notes that the Constitution permits a law laying down reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the rights mentioned in sub-clause (1)(d), and that the reasonableness has to be of the law also.
* The Court holds that the question which the Court has to consider is whether the restrictions put by the impugned legislation on the exercise of the right are reasonable or not.

**Final Ruling and Implications:**

* The petition is dismissed, and the impugned Act is upheld as imposing reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right to move throughout India.
* The ruling implies that the Court will consider the reasonableness of both the substantive and procedural parts of the law when determining whether restrictions on the exercise of a right are reasonable.

**Notable Legal Precedents Cited:**

* Article 19(5) of the Constitution, which permits the imposition of reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the rights conferred by sub-clauses (d), (e), and (f).
* Article 22(4) to (7) of the Constitution, which permits preventive detention for three months without any remedy.

**Conclusion:**

The ruling in this case sets a precedent for the consideration of reasonableness of both substantive and procedural parts of the law when determining whether restrictions on the exercise of a right are reasonable. The Court's decision upholds the impugned Act as imposing reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right to move throughout India, and provides guidance for future cases involving the interpretation of Article 19(5) of the Constitution.
